title: Opinion: Simone Biles makes two crazy-difficult skills look so easy. They are not
text:
CLOSE

STUTTGART, Germany -- Simone Biles topped the all-around standings by more than two points, got two new skills named after her and made the finals in all four events.

Ho-hum.

“Overall, I don’t know. I still feel like I could do better,” Biles said Saturday night when asked to assess her first day of competition at the world gymnastics championships. “But my goal going into tonight was not to do great, it was just to do well. I feel like I accomplished that.”

If you’re a gymnastics fan, savor this time. Even if you’re not a gymnastics fan but appreciate incredible achievements in sports, know that you are witnessing greatness.

Biles is so singularly talented that it’s easy to lose perspective at just how special an athlete she is. Like Michael Jordan, Tiger Woods or Michael Phelps in their heydays, the extraordinary has become the norm with her.

But there is nothing normal about what she is doing.

For any other gymnast, Saturday night’s performance would have been the defining one of her career. Biles posted the highest scores on both balance beam and floor exercise, and trailed teammate Jade Carey on vault by a mere .001 points.

Even on uneven bars, which made her want to “vomit … it was so bad,” Biles had the seventh-highest score.

And then, of course there were the new skills. Her triple-twisting, double somersault on floor exercise is so difficult, no other woman even tries it. Same for her double-twisting, double somersault on balance beam.

But it’s more than just the difficulty. There are plenty of gymnasts who try hard skills and look as if they’re inches away from death while doing them. Go watch some of the scary crashes on vault and you’ll see exactly what I mean.

Biles, though, doesn’t throw skills just to say she did them. If she’s going to compete at something, it’s going to be perfect. Or pretty darn close.

Take the double-double on beam. Or, as it will be known forever now, the Biles.

To pull it off, Biles has to twist while flipping, and it takes an incredible amount of power and precision to do it. Oftentimes she takes several seconds to marshal the energy she’s going to need before doing the trick.

On Saturday, though, she hesitated only briefly before running down the beam – which is only 4-inches wide, mind you, and 4 feet off the floor. And Biles did the double-double with such ease, that people who didn’t know what they were seeing probably thought it was a pretty standard move.

Which it most certainly is not.

Biles was grinning when she landed, and she ran off the podium clapping.

Simone Biles nailed her balance beam performance on Saturday. (Photo: Laurence Griffiths, Getty Images)

“That’s how I train beam. It finally felt good to go out there and hit a beam routine like I train because I feel like every time I go up to compete beam, I just like bomb it,” she said. “So it felt really good to nail it.”

And though she wouldn’t say it, send a message to the International Gymnastics Federation.

OPINION: Simone Biles penalized for having skills other gymnasts can't pull off

Every skill in gymnastics is assigned a letter, which corresponds to a numerical value. An “A” skill is worth a tenth of a point, and every letter in the alphabet that follows is an additional tenth. So a “D” skill is four-tenths of a point while the rare “J” skill is worth a full point.

The women’s technical committee decided this week that Biles’ double-double would be an “H” skill, while almost everyone else agrees it should be at least an “I.”

“They have a value too low,” national team coordinator Tom Forster said. “It needs to be up one more.”

The committee’s rationale was that it didn’t want to encourage gymnasts from trying skills they aren’t capable of. But the value of a skill is the value of a skill, and to punish Biles because of what other gymnasts “might” do is absurd.

Biles said she considered not doing it – why go through all that effort to do something so hard when it’s not going to be properly recognized? – but ultimately decided to go ahead. Time and again she has said that she’s not doing gymnastics for medals or titles – she already has plenty of those – but to see how far she can push herself.

“I’m so happy she has more skills named after her now because that’s been a really big deal for her,” Forster said. “And she did a great job.”

She always does.

Follow USA TODAY Sports columnist Nancy Armour on Twitter @nrarmour.
description: Simone Biles tops the all-around standings at the world gymnastics championships by more than two points after nailing two difficult new skills.
